title: url.parse() hostname spoofing via javascript: URIs
vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**

Using [url.parse()](https://nodejs.org/api/url.html#url_url_parse_urlstring_parsequerystring_slashesdenotehost) in security sensitive checks is dangerous as an arbitrary hostname can be spoofed via `javascript:` URIs. 

**Description:**

[The original url.parse() API](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/lib/url.js) is dangerous as it allows to spoof an arbitrary hostname via a `javascript:` URI:

```bash
$ node -e 'console.log(require("url").parse("javAscript:alert(1);a=\x27@white-listed.com\x27"))'
Url {
  protocol: 'javascript:',
  slashes: null,
  auth: 'alert(1);a=\'',
  host: 'white-listed.com',
  port: null,
  hostname: 'white-listed.com',
  hash: null,
  search: null,
  query: null,
  pathname: '\'',
  path: '\'',
  href: 'javascript:alert(1)%3Ba%3D\'@white-listed.com\'' }

```

**Steps To Reproduce:**

  1. `node -e 'console.log(require("url").parse("javAscript:alert(1);a=\x27@white-listed.com\x27"))'`

After a quick look, I believe the issue stems from case-sensitive checks on lines [268](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/lib/url.js#L268) and [275](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/lib/url.js#L275)

**Additional notes:**

I didn't set the severity as I have no idea how widely the "Legacy API" is still used and the actual impact is hugely context-based. For the sake of completeness, I found this issue when testing a real world app.

This also affects [this npm package](https://www.npmjs.com/package/url). 
The WHATWG API handles this particular case well.

In might be a good idea to mention in the documentation that URL parsing shouldn't be relied on in security relevant context. Exact string matching or similarly simple concepts should be always preferred.

## Impact

This can be dangerous if used in security relevant access controls as follows:

```js
let parsedUrl = UrlHelper.parse(url); // url = javAscript:alert(1);a='@localhost/'
if (parsedUrl.hostname === 'localhost') { // parsedUrl.hostname = localhost
  return true; // and do something like window.location = url 
}
```

Although being a bad practice, developers will write this code and will introduce bypassable access controls. Given that the bypass works only with `javascript:` URIs this will likely lead to XSS in most cases.
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:

Using url.parse() in security sensitive checks is dangerous as an arbitrary hostname can be spoofed via javascript: URIs.

Description:

The original url.parse() API is dangerous as it allows to spoof an arbitrary hostname via a javascript: URI:

$ node -e 'console.log(require("url").parse("javAscript:alert(1);a=\x27@white-listed.com\x27"))'
Url {
  protocol: 'javascript:',
  slashes: null,
  auth: 'alert(1);a=\'',
  host: 'white-listed.com',
  port: null,
  hostname: 'white-listed.com',
  hash: null,
  search: null,
  query: null,
  pathname: '\'',
  path: '\'',
  href: 'javascript:alert(1)%3Ba%3D\'@white-listed.com\'' }

Steps To Reproduce:

  1. node -e 'console.log(require("url").parse("javAscript:alert(1);a=\x27@white-listed.com\x27"))'

After a quick look, I believe the issue stems from case-sensitive checks on lines 268 and 275

Additional notes:

I didn't set the severity as I have no idea how widely the "Legacy API" is still used and the actual impact is hugely context-based. For the sake of completeness, I found this issue when testing a real world app.

This also affects this npm package.
The WHATWG API handles this particular case well.

In might be a good idea to mention in the documentation that URL parsing shouldn't be relied on in security relevant context. Exact string matching or similarly simple concepts should be always preferred.

Impact

This can be dangerous if used in security relevant access controls as follows:

let parsedUrl = UrlHelper.parse(url); // url = javAscript:alert(1);a='@localhost/'
if (parsedUrl.hostname === 'localhost') { // parsedUrl.hostname = localhost
  return true; // and do something like window.location = url 
}

Although being a bad practice, developers will write this code and will introduce bypassable access controls. Given that the bypass works only with javascript: URIs this will likely lead to XSS in most cases.

activities.message: Hey @bayotop thanks for submitting this report. The security team will review it and get back to you very soon!
activities.markdown_message: Hey @bayotop thanks for submitting this report. The security team will review it and get back to you very soon!

activities.message: Hi @mylesborins, by any chance are there any updates you could share? Thanks!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @mylesborins, by any chance are there any updates you could share? Thanks!

activities.message:
Hey Bayotop,

I've updated the severity index, do you think that seems accurate?

Apologies that our team hasn't reacted faster, a bunch of people (including myself) have been in and out of office.

It looks like we had a PR to runtime deprecate the legacy URL, https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/20270. It has landed and will be in Node.js 11.x. People said they would look in to how patch this bug. Will update when we have more details about how we plan to fix this.
activities.markdown_message:
Hey Bayotop,

I've updated the severity index, do you think that seems accurate?

Apologies that our team hasn't reacted faster, a bunch of people (including myself) have been in and out of office.

It looks like we had a PR to runtime deprecate the legacy URL, https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/20270. It has landed and will be in Node.js 11.x. People said they would look in to how patch this bug. Will update when we have more details about how we plan to fix this.

activities.message:
Hi @mylesborins,

Thanks for the update. The severity is fine by me.

I went through the changes and it's good to see that `tls`, `http`, and `https` modules will use the WHATWG URL parser. However unless I'm missing something, the legacy URL will still be available in Node.js 11.x. Consequently, existing apps leveraging `url.parse()` would still be affected. Is that correct?
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @mylesborins,

Thanks for the update. The severity is fine by me.

I went through the changes and it's good to see that tls, http, and https modules will use the WHATWG URL parser. However unless I'm missing something, the legacy URL will still be available in Node.js 11.x. Consequently, existing apps leveraging url.parse() would still be affected. Is that correct?

activities.message: We are working on a patch for earlier versions of node that would go out in a future security release. Will keep you updated as we reach consensus on the approach.
activities.markdown_message: We are working on a patch for earlier versions of node that would go out in a future security release. Will keep you updated as we reach consensus on the approach.

activities.message:
Unfortunately this report does not qualify for a bounty as "only critical vulnerabilities that demonstrate complete compromise of the system's integrity or confidentiality are eligible for a bounty - typically Arbitrary Code Execution or equivalent impact. While we encourage you to submit all potential issues, lower severity issues are not in scope at this time."

If you disagree with this assessment please let me know and we can revisit.

activities.message: Awesome @mylesborins. I agree regarding the bounty. Thanks for the updates!

activities.message: Just as a heads up we have a fix that is being reviewed. We are also picking a date for the security release. I'll keep you updated as soon as we have more information.
activities.markdown_message: Just as a heads up we have a fix that is being reviewed. We are also picking a date for the security release. I'll keep you updated as soon as we have more information.

activities.message:
We've had some time coming up with a speedy schedule for releasing a fix for this. Some high profile events that suck core-team time & user attention are getting in the way as well as Node 11 and Node 10 LTS this month. Plus we need to manage some other security fixes we'll be bundling with a release. The current plan we have is for an announcement on November the 12th and a release a week after.
@bayotop if you have any concerns with this schedule please let us know.

activities.message: No concerns here. Thanks for keeping me in the loop @mylesborins and @rvagg!
activities.markdown_message: No concerns here. Thanks for keeping me in the loop @mylesborins and @rvagg!

activities.message:
Just wanted to update you to let you know that the release is moving ahead as planned at the moment. Currently targeting a public announcement on Nov 13 and the release on Nov 20.

I'll update you if anything changes. Thank you so much for your patience.

activities.message:
Hey @bayotop, the fix for this is going out on the 27th as per https://nodejs.org/en/blog/vulnerability/november-2018-security-releases/

I'd love to put attribution on this item. If you're happy to have your name on it, could you please supply your name as you'd like it listed, and optionally, an organisation with which you're associated.

activities.message: Hi @rvagg, thanks for the update. Regarding attribution please use “Martin Bajanik”. If possible, linking the name to my Twitter profile (https://twitter.com/_bayotop) would be greatly appreciated.

activities.message: Additionally, I am associated with Kentico (https://kenticocloud.com).

activities.message: The fix is out and available in all versions of node. You can see our release post here --> https://nodejs.org/en/blog/vulnerability/november-2018-security-releases/#hostname-spoofing-in-url-parser-for-javascript-protocol-cve-2018-12123
